note.p: Letter from Marie Martin to her mother Mary Lewis Martin (n√©e Moore). Marie (1892-1975) was later the founder of the Medical Missionaries of Mary. At the outbreak of war in 1914 Marie joined the Voluntary Aid Detachment, a division of the Red Cross. She returned home briefly in 1916 following the death of her brother in battle until be called to serve again two months later in a field hospital in Heraldo, France.
In this letter Marie mentions her mother being ill with the mumps and that her brother Laurence John, also referred to as Jack, had a fever.

div.p:
Ever so many
thanks for your letters. I am
very distressed to hear of
all your worry & trouble
with the mumps etc. but
was delighted to receive
your card saying they were
all better. When you are so
busy & worried just get
someone to drop me a card
to say how you all are.

It is too bad about Jack
I cannot quite understand
how his temperature goes up
he really does not seem
very strong. I shall write
you a long letter in my
off time to-day but want
this to catch the post

It must be a great upset
to Ethel but a great use
to you to have her at
home. Have you had another
cold, do take care of your-
self. Hoping you continue
to have good news of
Tommy.

closer.salute:
My fondest love in
great haste
